articles.headline: For Punishment of Elder’s Misdeeds, Afghan Girl Pays the Price
articles.snippet: The illegal and denounced practice of “baad,” the giving of girls as payment for offenses committed by their relatives, is pervasive in parts of Afghanistan, according to human rights workers.
articles.abstract: The illegal and denounced practice of “baad,” the giving of girls as payment for offenses committed by their relatives, is pervasive in parts of Afghanistan, according to human rights workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASADABAD, Afghanistan — Shakila, 8 at the time, was drifting off to sleep when a group of men carrying AK-47s barged in through the door. She recalls that they complained, as they dragged her off into the darkness, about how their family had been dishonored and about how they had not been paid.

articles.headline: An Embargo and a Boon
articles.snippet: With a grade of oil closely resembling Iran’s, Russia could reap windfalls from European customers willing to pay premium prices.
articles.abstract: With a grade of oil closely resembling Iran’s, Russia could reap windfalls from European customers willing to pay premium prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — For months, the Russian government has opposed the idea of Western petroleum sanctions against Iran. But new threats to Iranian oil flow could have at least one beneficiary: Russia.

articles.headline: Germany vs. the Rest of Europe
articles.snippet: The German economy is faring well during a downturn, and resentment is rising among other euro zone countries.
articles.abstract: The German economy is faring well during a downturn, and resentment is rising among other euro zone countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: The German economy has been one of the wonders of the world over the last couple of years. While the rest of Europe staggered, German unemployment fell to the lowest level in decades.

articles.headline: Needing an Artist, and Calling on India
articles.snippet: A music video produced inexpensively in India illustrates the breadth of outsourcing, including specialized skills that were once considered unexportable.
articles.abstract: A music video produced inexpensively in India illustrates the breadth of outsourcing, including specialized skills that were once considered unexportable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Drew Smith found himself in the same position as many independent musicians trying to make a living in the struggling music business. He had no record label to underwrite his career, no publicity machine to get his music into listeners’ hands and not nearly enough money to make a music video.

articles.headline: Congress to Sell Public Airwaves to Pay Benefits
articles.snippet: The need to finance economic relief has pushed Congress to embrace a shift in the media landscape: the sale of airwaves now used for television to create more wireless Internet systems.
articles.abstract: The need to finance economic relief has pushed Congress to embrace a shift in the media landscape: the sale of airwaves now used for television to create more wireless Internet systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The need for revenue to partly cover the extension of the payroll tax cut and long-term unemployment benefits has pushed Congress to embrace a generational shift in the country’s media landscape: the auction of public airwaves now used for television broadcasts to create more wireless Internet systems.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: At Work in Syria, Times Correspondent Dies
articles.snippet: Anthony Shadid, a prize-winning journalist, was reporting inside Syria when he suffered a fatal asthma attack.
articles.abstract: Anthony Shadid, a prize-winning journalist, was reporting inside Syria when he suffered a fatal asthma attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anthony Shadid, a gifted foreign correspondent whose graceful dispatches for The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Boston Globe and The Associated Press covered nearly two decades of Middle East conflict and turmoil, died, apparently of an asthma attack, on Thursday while on a reporting assignment in Syria. Tyler Hicks, a Times photographer who was with Mr. Shadid, carried his body across the border to Turkey.

articles.headline: U.S. to Review Diet Treatment Once Rejected
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration will review a new diet pill consisting of a combination of two pills people are using in California to lose weight.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration will review a new diet pill consisting of a combination of two pills people are using in California to lose weight.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS OSOS, Calif. — Next week, advisers to the Food and Drug Administration will recommend whether the agency should approve the first new prescription diet pill in 13 years.

articles.headline: Countries Seek Retaliation to Europe’s Carbon Tax on Airlines
articles.snippet: China, the United States and two dozen other countries are looking at measures to squeeze European airlines and other industries if the European Union tries to enforce the new law.
articles.abstract: China, the United States and two dozen other countries are looking at measures to squeeze European airlines and other industries if the European Union tries to enforce the new law.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — China, the United States and two dozen other countries are looking at coordinated retaliation — including putting pressure on European airlines and other industries — if Europe tries to enforce a law requiring airlines to pay for their greenhouse gas emissions.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Nicola Clark
